Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2008 06:55AM shafali wrote: Hi Cheryl, I think most of us here have been on a few while dealing with all this. In 2003 after my initial dx and surgery, I did 4 cycles of FEC then a break for radiation then 4 cycles of Taxotere. Tamox and Arimidex for 3 and a half years. Then bone mets in April 2007. Did 2 cycles of Herceptin with Taxotere, followed by 6 cycles of Herceptin with Navelbine. Now am doing 4 cycles of just Herceptin. Then a PET scan and then we shall see. Each time it rears its ugly head, just fight it with whatever works. The side effects do sometime seem as bad as the disease .......... Hope you are feeling better. Love Bubble

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 05:19AM shafali wrote: Hi Was intially diagnosed at stage II in 2003 at age 32. (30 of 36 nodes positive!, ER+, PR+, Her2neu+++) Did 4CEF+ radiation + 4 Taxotere. Then tamoxifen for 3 years. Arimidex for 6mnths. NED  for almost 4 years During a routine annual bone scan in April 2007, they found a single area on the spine. Did Aromasin + Bondronate (bone strengthening med) for 3 months. As we (me n the onc) wanted to tackle it aggresively, am now on 2 cycles of Herceptin + taxotere followed by 10 of herceptin + navalbine.(all cycles of 21 days)  Bondronate continues. Will beat it this time. Love n luck Shafali

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 07:58AM shafali wrote: Hi I have done Taxotere twice. The acidity is quite bad, but there is a medicine that you can take in the morning or before meals that really helps (here in India its called Ocid - if you want I can find out the salt so you can try an equivalent med there) The aches and the feeling of fatigue was quite severe for me especially the second time around. But it lasted only a few days and   just a tylenol kind of drug helped me. Love n luck Shafali
Posts.Title: shooting pains Tracy1964 shafali

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 01:20AM shafali wrote: Hi Generally the word 'recurrance' is used if the cancer has come back after the initial diagnosis (locally in the same breast, or regionally in the same area or at a distant spot) and mets (Metastistic) is if it has spread to distant areas (bones, organs, etc.). Mets may be diagnosed with the initial diagnosis or at a later stage. Hope you daughter is doing well. If you post a few more details of your daughter's diagnosis then probably you would get a more detailed feedback from this board. Love and luck Bubble

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 07:13AM shafali wrote: Hi Danie, I was diagonsed with bone mets last year. Pain is the very first syptom and thats what generally alerts the doc to do some detailed tests. I live in India and have a great doc. I get my bone scan done as a part of my annual check up (after the intial diagnosis in 2003). I did have some pain in the back which I ignored, but the bone scan caught the problem while it was limited to one area. Hope you are doing well. Love and luck Bubble
Posts.Title: How was your bone mets diagnosed Danie awjkej

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 07:25AM shafali wrote: Hi Danie, My intial diagnosis was in May 2003 at Stage 2. ER+, PR+, Her2neu+++, Surgery, chemo and radiation folloed by Tamoxifen for 3 years and Arimidex for 6 months. Mets was caught in the annual scans in April 2007. It is in one area on the spine. Removing it wasn't even an option that we discussed.   I was put on further hormonal treatment (Aromasin) and a bone strengthener called Bonronate which is like Zometa but in tablet form - It's not commonly used in US but is quite common in Europe (and is made by the same pharma company which makes Herceptin). But since both, my doc and I, wanted to be really aggressive we decided to move to chemo + Herceptin and continue with Bondronate. I started this treatment in Aug 2007 and the pain disappeared after the very first dose. I finish the course in April and then am planning on having a PET scan to check on things and plan the next course of action with my Oncologist. I too feel that since the problem is in one area alone, the chances of getting rid of it are that much better. Did you have any blood test for tumour markers? Also is your doc planning to do a PET scan to confirm the diagnosis. Couple of things that I have read about on the net and some stuff which other women on these sites have told me: - No one dies of just bone mets - It is the easiest to manage and treat - Most of the docs now consider it a chronic disease like diabetes and so on - All the statistics on the net should be ignored as each person is different and I read of many women living with mets (not just bone mets) for 15 / 20 years and more.  - Also all the statistics are for the older treatments - they don't really reflect the success of the newer treatments I am glad that you are getting a second opinion on things - it helps so much. Hope you are doing better. Let me know what treatment you are planning to take. Hugs Bubble
Posts.Title: How was your bone mets diagnosed Danie awjkej
